{{other people||Holsinger (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = James W. Holsinger Jr. |image = Holsinger University Portrait.jpg | office = [[Kentucky]] Cabinet Secretary for Health and Family Services | term_start = 2003 | term_end = 2005 | office2 = [[Chancellor (education)|Chancellor]] [[University of Kentucky]]'s [[Chandler Medical Center]] | term_start2 = 1994 | term_end2 = 2003 | office3 = Under Secretary of Veterans Affairs for Health | order3 = 13th | term_start3 = 1990 | term_end3 = 1993 |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1939|05|11}} | birth_place = {{flagicon|USA}} [[Kansas City, Kansas]] | death_date = | death_place = | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] | spouse = Barbara Craig Holsinger, Ph.D. | residence = [[Lexington, Kentucky]] | alma_mater = [[Duke University]]
[[University of Kentucky]]
[[University of South Carolina]]
[[Asbury Theological Seminary]] | occupation = medicine, public health | religion = [[Methodist]] | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''James Wilson Holsinger Jr.''', (born May 11, 1939) is an American [[physician]]. A former [[Major General (United States)|major general]] in the [[United States Army Reserve|U.S. Army Reserve]] (1962 to 1993), he has worked primarily in [[public health]] for over thirty years. He served as the [[Under Secretary of Veterans Affairs for Health]] from 1990 to 1993, during the administrations of [[George H. W. Bush]] and [[Bill Clinton]].{{cite web |date=November 22, 1991 |url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?sec=health&res=9D0CEFD71F3DF931A15752C1A967958260 |title= Investigator Cites Poor Care at Veterans Hospitals |publisher= [[The New York Times]] |accessdate=2007-07-19}} From 1994 to 2003, Holsinger was the [[Chancellor (education)|Chancellor]] of the [[University of Kentucky]]'s [[Chandler Medical Center]]. From 2003 to 2005 he served as [[Kentucky]]'s Secretary of Health and Family Services. On May 24, 2007, [[President of the United States|President]] [[George W. Bush]] nominated Holsinger to become the [[Surgeon General of the United States]]. Holsinger's nomination became controversial and was never voted on by the Senate due to, according to his critics, anti-gay bias in his work in the United Methodist Church where he voted to expel a lesbian pastor and for a 1991 report where he characterized gay sex as unnatural and unhealthy.{{cite web |date= January 7, 2009 |url= http://www.whas11.com/news/local/stories/090107whasasMedicalHoslinger.8fdeea.html |title= Kentucky doctor appointed to President's Council on Physical Fitness |publisher= [[The Associated Press]] |accessdate= January 7, 2009 }}{{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite web |date= January 7, 2009 |last= Vos |first= Sarah |url= http://www.kentucky.com/179/story/648677.html |title= Holsinger named to fitness panel |publisher= [[Lexington Herald]] |accessdate= January 7, 2009 }} In January 2009, instead, Bush appointed Holsinger to fill a vacant unpaid position on the [[President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports]] to expire May 2010. Holsinger obtained his medical degree in 1964 and a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] in [[anatomy]] in 1968, both from [[Duke University]]. {{As of|2009}}, he is a professor at the University of Kentucky. Holsinger is a leader in the [[United Methodist Church]], serving as treasurer of the [[World Methodist Council]] and was previously President of the Judicial Council. ==Early life and education== [[File:Holsinger and Mother.jpg|thumb|right|Holsinger with mother]]Holsinger was born in [[Kansas City, Kansas]], to James W. Holsinger Sr. (1906–1994), an Army [[Brigadier General (United States)|brigadier general]], and Ruth Reitz Holsinger (b. 1909).{{cite web |date=February 24, 1994 |url= http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/jwholsinger.htm |title= James Wilson Holsinger, Brigadier General |publisher= [[Arlington National Cemetery]] |accessdate=2007-07-22}}{{cite web |date=November 19, 2005 |url= http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=LH&p_theme=lh&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_dispstring=Holsinger%20will%20be%20tough%20act%20to%20follow%20AND%20date(all)&p_field_advanced-0=&p_text_advanced-0=(Holsinger%20will%20be%20tough%20act%20to%20follow)&xcal_numdocs=20&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&xcal_useweights=no |title= Holsinger will be tough act to follow |publisher= [[Lexington Herald-Leader]] |pages= A12}} Holsinger graduated from [[Duke University]] with an [[Doctor of Medicine|M.D.]] in 1964 and a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] in [[anatomy]] in 1968. He holds a degree from the [[University of Kentucky]] in human studies. Additionally, he holds [[master's degree]]s in hospital financial management from the [[University of South Carolina]], as well as [[biblical studies]] from the [[Asbury Theological Seminary]].{{cite web |year=2006 |author= Holsinger, James W. |url= http://www.ukcph.org/Portals/0/CVs/HSM/James%20Holsinger%20CV.pdf |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070929105319/http://www.ukcph.org/Portals/0/CVs/HSM/James%20Holsinger%20CV.pdf |dead-url= yes |archive-date= 2007-09-29 |title= James W. Holsinger, Curriculum Vitae |publisher= [[University of Kentucky]] |accessdate=2007-07-22|format=PDF }}{{cite web |date = May 25, 2007 |author = Blanton, Jay |url = http://news.uky.edu/news/display_article.php?artid=2325 |title = UK, State Officials Praise Nomination of James Holsinger |publisher = [[University of Kentucky]] News |accessdate = 2007-07-22 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110719031014/http://news.uky.edu/news/display_article.php?artid=2325 |archivedate = July 19, 2011 |df = }} He served as a surgical resident at [[Duke University Medical Center]] and [[Shands at the University of Florida|Shands Teaching Hospital]] where he was also a fellow in Cardiology. Holsinger has published four medical books and sixty-one [[peer review|peer-reviewed]] papers. ==Government career== ===Department of Veterans Affairs=== [[File:James W Holsinger official military portrait - 1993.jpg|thumb|left|Holsinger Major General Portrait]]Holsinger served for twenty-six years in the [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs]] (VA) from 1969 to 1994.{{cite web |date=May 25, 2007 |author= Gerth, Joseph |url= http://www.courier-journal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070525/NEWS01/705250431 |archive-url= https://archive.is/20130119165933/http://www.courier-journal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070525/NEWS01/705250431 |dead-url= yes |archive-date= January 19, 2013 |title= Bush taps Kentuckian as surgeon general |publisher= [[Courier-Journal]] |accessdate=2007-07-22}} He served at five different hospitals, rising to become a Medical Center Director. In 1990, President George H. W. Bush appointed Holsinger as Chief Medical Director of the VA (title changed to [[Under Secretary of Veterans Affairs for Health]] in 1992).{{cite web |url= http://www.ukcph.org/Academics/HealthServicesManagement/HSMFacultyList/JamesHolsinger/tabid/599/Default.aspx |title= James W. Holsinger |publisher= [[University of Kentucky]] |accessdate=2007-07-22 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070929105325/http://www.ukcph.org/Academics/HealthServicesManagement/HSMFacultyList/JamesHolsinger/tabid/599/Default.aspx |archivedate = 2007-09-29}} He implemented the joint VA and [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] Contingency Hospital System, which could provide 25,000 beds within seventy-two hours for soldiers fighting in [[Kuwait]] during the first [[Gulf War|Iraq War]].{{cite web |date=July 12, 2007 |author= Holsinger, James W. |url= http://help.senate.gov/Hearings/2007_07_12/Holsinger.pdf |title= Prepared Statement of James W. Holsinger Jr., MD. |publisher= [[United States Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions]] |accessdate=2007-07-22|format=PDF |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070725185621/http://help.senate.gov/Hearings/2007_07_12/Holsinger.pdf |archivedate = 2007-07-25}}{{cite web |date=September 28, 2006 |author= |url= http://www1.va.gov/EMSHG/page.cfm?pg=61 |title= VA/DoD Contingency |publisher= [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs]] |accessdate=2007-07-22}} He oversaw the nation's largest [[health care system]], which served one million in-patients and twenty million out-patient visits per year. Holsinger also developed [[health care]] policy for twenty-six million veterans.{{cite web |url= http://www1.va.gov/health/gateway.html |title= Veteran Health Administration - Programs & Organizations. |publisher= [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs]] |accessdate=2007-07-22}} When Holsinger assumed the post of Chief Medical Director, the VA was criticized for the quality of the care it provided. In 1991, Holsinger acknowledged that inadequate care had caused the deaths of six patients at its North Chicago hospital.{{cite web |date=April 7, 1991 |url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?sec=health&res=9D0CEFDE133DF934A35757C0A967958260 |title= U.S. Links 6 Deaths to Poor Hospital Care |publisher= [[Associated Press]] |accessdate=2007-07-22}} He commissioned a team to review the quality of care, and based on its findings suspended surgical care at the facility. Later, testimony before a [[United States Congress|Congressional]] subcommittee reported problems at more than thirty other veterans' hospitals. Holsinger responded, "Our patients are older, sicker and more complex than the average patient." In 1993, he moved to Kentucky to become the Director of the VA Medical Center. He remained a consultant in cardiology for the hospital until 2003. Holsinger was awarded the [[Surgeon General's Medal]] by Surgeon General [[Antonia Novello]]. ===United States Army Reserve=== Holsinger served for over thirty-one years in the [[United States Army Reserve]]. He was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Medal (U.S. Army)|Distinguished Service Medal]], the [[Legion of Merit]] and the [[Meritorious Service Medal (United States)|Meritorious Service Medal]] three times. He was assigned to the [[Joint Chiefs of Staff]] and promoted to [[Major General (United States)|major general]] in medical logistics working at [[the Pentagon]] under General [[Colin Powell]]. Holsinger retired from the United States Army Reserve in 1993. ==Academic career== ===University of Kentucky administration=== [[File:Gill Heart Institute University Kentucky 2007.jpg|thumb|right|Gill Heart Institute]] From 1994 to 2003, Holsinger served as [[Chancellor]] of the [[University of Kentucky Medical Center]] with responsibility for five health colleges, four graduate centers, two hospitals, and numerous clinics in Kentucky.{{cite web |url = http://www.uky.edu/Regulations/Org/MedCente.pdf |title = University of Kentucky Chancellor's Office. Organizational Charts |publisher = [[University of Kentucky]] |accessdate = 2007-07-22 |format = PDF |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071202152312/http://www.uky.edu/Regulations/Org/MedCente.pdf |archivedate = 2007-12-02 |df = }} Under Holsinger's leadership, the university built the [[Gill Heart Institute (University of Kentucky)|Gill Heart Institute]] and two research buildings, and Holsinger laid the groundwork for the expansion the hospital has undergone since he left. Holsinger helped establish the Women's Health Center and the College of Public Health. In 2004, he was named a Master in the [[American College of Physicians]].{{cite web |date = March 2004 |url = http://www.acponline.org/journals/news/march04/awards.htm |title = College announces service awardees and new Masters |publisher = ACP Observer |accessdate = 2007-07-22 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928004335/http://www.acponline.org/journals/news/march04/awards.htm |archivedate = 2007-09-28 |df = }} In the late 1990s, Holsinger led an international team to address the [[AIDS]] epidemic in [[sub-Saharan Africa]]. Working with [[Africa University]] in [[Zimbabwe]], the team created a School of Health Sciences with nursing and public health programs to educate young people to deal with the AIDS crisis. Holsinger helped the university obtain a [[USAID]] grant to build the facility, which houses one of the few AIDS laboratories in southern Africa.{{cite web |url= http://www.gbhem.org/asp/viewNews.asp?id=241 |title= Africa University dedicates health sciences building |publisher= General Board of Higher education and ministry |accessdate=2007-07-22}} In 2007, the program is preparing to field-test an [[HIV]] vaccine.{{cite web |date=July 12, 2007 |url= http://help.senate.gov/Hearings/2007_07_12/2007_07_12.html |title= Witness Testimony |publisher= [[United States Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions]] |accessdate=2007-07-22 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070712142932/http://help.senate.gov/Hearings/2007_07_12/2007_07_12.html |archivedate = 2007-07-12}} ===University of Kentucky faculty=== After spending two years in Kentucky state government, he returned to the University of Kentucky as a professor for the graduate program in Public Health. In 2011, Holsinger was inducted into University of Kentucky College of Public Health Hall of Fame for his service and dedication.{{cite web |date= March 30, 2016 |author= |url= http://www.uky.edu/publichealth/about/hall-fame/past-inductees |title= Hall of Fame Past Inductees |publisher= [[University of Kentucky]] |accessdate=2016-03-30}} Holsinger is currently the Wethington Endowed Chair in the Health Sciences, Professor of Preventive Medicine and Health Management & Policy.{{cite web |date= March 30, 2016 |author= |url= http://www.uky.edu/publichealth/about/faculty-and-staff-directory/james-w-holsinger |title= James W. Holsinger |publisher= [[University of Kentucky]] |accessdate=2016-03-30}} ==Political career== ===Kentucky state government=== [[File:Frankfort Kentucky Capitol Building 2007.jpg|thumb|left|Capitol, Frankfort Kentucky]]Holsinger served as Secretary of the Cabinet for Health and Family Services for Kentucky under Governor [[Ernie Fletcher]].{{cite web |date=June 10, 2007 |author= Vos, Sarah |url= http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=LH&p_theme=lh&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_dispstring=Criticism%20surprises%20Holsinger%20colleagues%20AND%20date(all)&p_field_advanced-0=&p_text_advanced-0=(Criticism%20surprises%20Holsinger%20colleagues)&xcal_numdocs=20&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&xcal_useweights=no |title= Criticism surprises Holsinger colleagues |publisher= [[Lexington Herald-Leader]] |accessdate=2007-07-22}} He was responsible for the management of the state's health and social services programs, including the five billion dollar Kentucky [[Medicaid]] program.{{cite web |url= http://chfs.ky.gov/agencies/os/mission.htm |title= CHFS Mission-Vision |publisher= Kentucky Cabinet for Health and Family Services |accessdate=2007-07-22 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071221204458/http://chfs.ky.gov/agencies/os/mission.htm |archivedate=2007-12-21}}{{cite web |url= http://chfs.ky.gov/NR/rdonlyres/F4DE5941-6E93-40FE-B204-42B63A95DA80/0/CHFSExecutiveOrganizationalChart080806.pdf |title= CHFS Executive Organizational Chart |publisher= Kentucky Cabinet for Health and Family Services |accessdate=2007-07-22|format=PDF}} Holsinger also led the social services response to the 6,000 evacuees of [[Hurricane Katrina]] who relocated to Kentucky. While serving as Secretary, Holsinger published a paper on physician professionalism stating that the autonomous practice of medicine contributes to physician dissatisfaction because of the prevalence of third-party payers and liability concerns. He recommended a new professional structure based on teamwork between physicians and "fair access to health care for all Americans."{{cite web |year= 2006 |author= Holsinger, James W. |url= http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi-bin/fulltext/112467527/PDFSTART |title= Physician Professionalism for a New Century |publisher= Clinical Anatomy |accessdate=2007-07-22}} The ''[[Associated Press]]'' said Holsinger was a financial supporter of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]].{{cite web |date=July 13, 2007 |author= Alonso-Zaldivar, Ricardo |url= http://www.newsobserver.com/nation_world/story/635819.html |title= Support is slow coming for surgeon general pick |publisher= [[The Associated Press]] |accessdate=2007-07-20}}{{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} According to ''[[The Courier-Journal]]'', he contributed $23,000 over ten years to the party and its candidates, including President [[George W. Bush]]. ==Religious life== ===Good Samaritan Foundation=== [[File:Holsinger's Hope Springs Church 2007.jpg|thumb|right|Holsinger's current church]] While Holsinger served as [[chair (official)|chair]] of the board of the Good Samaritan Foundation, a [[philanthropic]] [[health care]] organization, the [[United Methodist Church]] of Kentucky sued the foundation over control of $20 million in assets. Holsinger said the church was "only interested in the foundation's money, not its cause." In October, 2007, the case was decided in the church's favor.{{cite web |date = October 17, 2007 |author = Green, Linda |url = http://www.umc.org/site/apps/nl/content3.asp?c=lwL4KnN1LtH&b=2072519&ct=4535587 |title = Kentucky Conference wins lawsuit with foundation |publisher = [[United Methodist Church]] |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071103101706/http://www.umc.org/site/apps/nl/content3.asp?c=lwL4KnN1LtH&b=2072519&ct=4535587 |archivedate = November 3, 2007 |df = }} ===Asbury Theological Seminary=== In November, 2007, the [[Asbury Theological Seminary]] [[board of trustees]] attempted to remove Holsinger from its board for a possible [[conflict of interest]] because he was also a board member of the [[Association of Theological Schools in the United States and Canada]], a division of which was investigating the [[Educational accreditation|accreditation]] status of the [[seminary]]. According to Holsinger, he subsequently resigned because he believed the board was asking him to be less than truthful with regulatory agencies.{{cite news |date=2007-11-16 |title= Holsinger quits Asbury board |publisher= [[The Associated Press]] |accessdate=2007-11-16}}{{cite news |url = http://m.courier-journal.com/detail.jsp?key=155692&full=1 |date = 2007-11-15 |author = Smith, Peter |title = Holsinger quits Asbury board |publisher = [[The Courier-Journal]] |accessdate = 2008-03-26 }}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Nomination for Surgeon General== ===Confirmation process=== [[File:Holsinger and Koop.jpg|thumb|right|Holsinger with Surgeon General Koop 2007]] On May 24, 2007, Holsinger was nominated by George W. Bush to become the 18th Surgeon General of the United States. The [[United States Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions|Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions]] (HELP) held the confirmation hearing on July 12, 2007.{{cite web |date=July 13, 2007 |author= Harris, Gardiner |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/13/washington/13surgeon.html |title= Nominee for Surgeon General Testifies in Senate |publisher= [[The New York Times]] |accessdate=2007-07-19}} Holsinger was supported by the [[American College of Physicians]] and former Surgeons General [[C. Everett Koop]] and [[Joycelyn Elders]]. He was opposed by several gay and lesbian organizations and the [[American Public Health Association]].{{cite web |date=July 13, 2007 |author= Carroll, James |url= http://www.courier-journal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070713/NEWS01/707130447 |archive-url= https://archive.is/20130119182026/http://www.courier-journal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070713/NEWS01/707130447 |dead-url= yes |archive-date= January 19, 2013 |title= Surgeon general nominee vows science comes first |publisher= [[The Courier-Journal]] |accessdate=2007-07-19}}{{cite web |date=November 16, 2007 |author= Warren, Jim |url= http://www.kentucky.com/181/story/232897.html |title= Ex-surgeon general wonders: Is Holsinger's confirmation ordeal worth it? |publisher= [[Lexington Herald-Leader]] |accessdate=2007-11-16}}{{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} In October 2007, [[Scripps Howard News Service]] reported that the nomination was in trouble though he retained the support of several Republicans and the White House. The Senate committee was waiting for Holsinger to answer follow-up questions from the July confirmation hearing.{{cite news |date=2007-10-15 |last=Thompson |first=Justin |url=http://news.cincypost.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20071015/NEWS01/710150383 |title=Surgeon general nominee on hold |work=[[The Cincinnati Post]] (Scripps Howard News Service) |publisher=[[E. W. Scripps Company]] |accessdate=2007-10-15 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071018021017/http://news.cincypost.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20071015%2FNEWS01%2F710150383 |archivedate=2007-10-18 |deadurl=yes |df= }} On November 16, 2007, ''[[The Politico]]'' and the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' reported that due to rumors that Holsinger would be [[recess appointment|recess appointed]], [[Party leaders of the United States Senate|Senate Majority Leader]] [[Harry Reid]] would convene the chamber several times during the two-week Thanksgiving break, effectively avoiding adjourning the Senate and preventing any recess appointment.{{cite web |date=November 16, 2007 |author= Bresnahan, John |url= http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/11/16/politics/politico/thecrypt/main3516002.shtml |title= Reid To Bush: No Recess Appointments Wanted |publisher= [[The Politico]] |accessdate=2007-11-19}}{{cite web |date=November 18, 2007 |author=Levey, Noam N. |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/politics/la-na-recess18nov18,0,5153317.story?coll=la-politics-campaign |title=Senate isn't exactly out of town |publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=2007-11-19 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080114040822/http://www.latimes.com/news/politics/la-na-recess18nov18%2C0%2C5153317.story?coll=la-politics-campaign |archivedate=January 14, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The same tactic was used for the 2007 holiday break.{{cite web |date=December 21, 2007 |url= http://www.wkyt.com/news/headlines/12738167.html |title= Senators Try To Block Nomination Of KY Doctor |publisher= [[WKYT]] |accessdate=2007-12-21}}{{cite web |date=December 21, 2007 |author= Abdullah, Halimah |url= http://www.kentucky.com/454/story/265062.html |title= Senate Democrats dig in to block Bush's appointing of Holsinger |publisher= [[Lexington Herald-Leader]] |accessdate=2007-12-21 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080104121655/http://www.kentucky.com/454/story/265062.html |archivedate = 2008-01-04}} Given the Democratic resistance coupled with Holsinger's lack of response to the committee's questions after more than ten months, in June 2008, thirteen months after his nomination, Kentucky Senator [[Jim Bunning]], a Holsinger supporter, suggested the nomination was dead which the White House and fellow Kentucky Senator and [[Senate Minority Leader]] [[Mitch McConnell]] denied. The political scientist [[Norman Ornstein]] said, "It's extremely unusual for somebody not to answer questions. It's a big fat 'dis' of the committee and of the Senate. Even if you know or believe you are not likely to be confirmed, the idea that you wouldn't sort of do what the committee has asked is still kind of mind-boggling." The committee's Republican [[ranking member]] said Holsinger's lack of response was "not helpful" while the [[editorial board]] of Kentucky's [[Courier-Journal]] characterized it as "disrespectful" and "baffling".{{cite web |date= 2008-06-18 |last= Abdullah |first= Halimah |url= http://www.kentucky.com/779/story/436658.html |title= Bunning: Holsinger to get snub |publisher= [[Lexington Herald-Leader]] |accessdate= 2008-06-18 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080622120917/http://www.kentucky.com/779/story/436658.html |archivedate = 2008-06-22}}{{cite web |date= 2008-06-24 |last= Carroll |first= James R. |url= http://www.courier-journal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080624/NEWS01/806240386 |title= Time running out for surgeon general nominee |publisher= [[Courier-Journal]] |accessdate= 2008-06-24 |quote= }}{{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite web |date= 2008-06-25 |url= http://www.courier-journal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080625/OPINION01/806250767 |archive-url= https://archive.is/20130119182935/http://www.courier-journal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080625/OPINION01/806250767 |dead-url= yes |archive-date= 2013-01-19 |title= Holsinger's silence |publisher= [[Courier-Journal]] |accessdate= 2008-06-25 |quote= It is simply baffling that he would give up the nomination so easily. }} The nomination was never voted on by the Senate and afterwards, in January 2009, Bush appointed him to fill a vacant unpaid position on the [[President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports]] to expire May 2010. ===Nomination controversy=== Following the nomination, Holsinger's views on homosexuality came under scrutiny, and several Democratic senators expressed concern or opposition to the nomination. In addition, individuals released statements supporting or opposing the nomination. Kevin Naff, editor of the [[LGBT]] newspaper, the ''[[Washington Blade]]'', charged that Holsinger has a "long record of anti-gay bias."{{cite web |date=June 22, 2007 |author= Naff, Kevin |url= http://www.washblade.com/2007/6-22/view/editorial/10821.cfm |title= Dems should derail Holsinger |publisher= [[Washington Blade]] |accessdate=2007-07-19 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928014639/http://www.washblade.com/2007/6-22/view/editorial/10821.cfm |archivedate = 2007-09-28}} [[Paul Weyrich]], the conservative commentator, said opposition to Holsinger's nomination amounted to an assault on religious freedom.{{cite web |date=June 27, 2007 |author= Weyrich, Paul |url= http://www.renewamerica.us/columns/weyrich/070627 |title= A new (unconstitutional) religious test for a presidential appointee? |publisher= [[Renew America]] |accessdate=2007-07-19 |authorlink= Paul Weyrich}} Still others asserted that Holsinger is not hostile to homosexuals citing his support for a session on lesbian health issues at a health conference and the support of a former colleague who is a lesbian.{{cite web |date=June 9, 2007 |author= Banerjee, Neela |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/09/washington/09surgeon.html |title= Surgeon General Nominee Is Assailed for Church Role |publisher= [[New York Times]] |accessdate=2007-07-19}} The critics were largely concerned with a 1991 [[white paper]] he wrote titled ''[http://abcnews.go.com/images/Politics/Holsinger_on_Homosexuality.pdf Pathophysiology of Male Homosexuality]'' for a committee in the United Methodist Church reviewing its position that homosexuality violates Christian teaching. According to [[Jake Tapper]] of [[ABC News]], the paper "purported" to discuss homosexuality from a medical standpoint.{{cite web |date=June 7, 2007 |author= Tapper, Jake |url= http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/story?id=3251663&page=1 |title= Homosexuality Isn't Natural or Healthy |publisher= [[ABC News]] |accessdate=2007-07-19 |authorlink= Jake Tapper}} But the Rev. [[J. Philip Wogaman]], the main writer for the committee, said Holsinger imposed his views of homosexuality in the report. According to Wogaman, Holsinger resigned after he anticipated that the committee was preparing to support the moral dignity of non-promiscuous homosexuality. The church never adopted the committee's recommendations{{cite web |date = July 12, 2007 |author = Tooley, Mark |url = http://www.spectator.org/dsp_article.asp?art_id=11720 |title = Can a Methodist Be U.S. Surgeon General? |publisher = [[The American Spectator]] |accessdate = 2007-07-21 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930152326/http://www.spectator.org/dsp_article.asp?art_id=11720 |archivedate = September 30, 2007 |df = }} but continues to struggle with the issue.{{cite web |year= 2004 |author= Task Force on Homosexuality and the Unity of the Church |url= http://archives.umc.org/interior.asp?ptid=4&mid=6571 |title= Report of the Task Force on Homosexuality and the Unity of the Church |publisher= [[United Methodist Church]] archives |accessdate=2007-07-21}} Supporters of Holsinger's nomination defended the paper as a review of the relevant medical literature at that time. Critics said the paper reflected a pre-1970s view of human sexuality, and that it had a political agenda and was not a scientific paper. At his confirmation hearing, Holsinger said the paper did not represent his current views and was not "an example of my scientific work." Critics have also expressed concerns about Holsinger's leadership of The United Methodist Church's Judicial Council, the highest court of the Church. In 2005, the court defrocked [[Irene Elizabeth Stroud]], an openly lesbian minister, and in a separate case reinstated a pastor who had been suspended for refusing to allow a gay man to join his congregation.{{cite web |date=November 1, 2005 |author= Banerjee, Neela |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2005/11/01/national/01methodists.html?scp=1&sq=Top+Methodist+Court+Backs+Conservatives+on+Gay+Issues&st=nyt |title= Top Methodist Court Backs Conservatives on Gay Issues |publisher= [[New York Times]] |accessdate=2008-03-28}}{{cite web |date=October 31, 2005 |author= Caldwell, Neill |url= http://www.umc.org/site/c.gjJTJbMUIuE/b.1144999/k.E558/Church_court_reinstates_pastor_who_denied_membership_to_gay_man.htm |title= Church court reinstates pastor who denied membership to gay man |publisher= News Archives [[United Methodist Church]] |accessdate=2007-07-19}} However, a Judicial Council member said that the decisions should not be read as Holsinger's personal views because the council does not have the power to establish church law and lacked the discretion to rule otherwise. But, as the ''[[New York Times]]'' noted, "some council members opposed his views, and the bishops later rejected one decision."{{cite web |date=July 10, 2007 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/10/opinion/10tue1.html |title= A Nominee's Abnormal Views |publisher= [[New York Times]] |accessdate=2008-03-28}}{{cite web |date=May 30, 2006 |author= Caldwell, Neill |url= http://www.umc.org/site/c.gjJTJbMUIuE/b.1616949/k.D165/Bishops_president_foresees_more_dialogue_after_judicial_session.htm |title= Bishops' president foresees more dialogue after judicial session |publisher= News Archives of the United Methodist Church |accessdate=2007-07-18}} On October 24, 2007, Holsinger announced he would not participate in the fall Judicial Council meeting set to decide on a case involving the appointment of a [[transgender]] clergy member,{{cite web |date=October 24, 2007 |url= http://www.wfn.org/2007/10/msg00184.html |title= Holsinger decides not to participate in top court's fall meeting |publisher= |accessdate=2007-10-24}} which upheld the appointment.{{cite web |date = October 30, 2007 |author = Locke, Michelle |url = http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5g7U2BJ8HdNdUXQVCHBt60-tq15eAD8SJTPKO0 |title = Methodist Transgender Minister May Stay |publisher = [[Associated Press]] |accessdate = 2007-10-31 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071102092824/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5g7U2BJ8HdNdUXQVCHBt60-tq15eAD8SJTPKO0 |archivedate = November 2, 2007 |df = }}{{cite web |date = October 30, 2007 |author = Caldwell, Neill |url = http://www.umc.org/site/apps/nl/content3.asp?c=lwL4KnN1LtH&b=1723955&ct=4565265 |title = Top court upholds transgender pastor's appointment |publisher = News Archives of the United Methodist Church. |accessdate = 2007-10-31 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080110225728/http://www.umc.org/site/apps/nl/content3.asp?c=lwL4KnN1LtH&b=1723955&ct=4565265 |archivedate = January 10, 2008 |df = }} Holsinger completed his 8-year term as a Judicial Council member and his 4-year term as its president in May 2008.{{cite web |date= 2008-04-28 |url= http://www.wfn.org/2008/04/msg00257.html |title= Five new members are elected to Judicial Council |publisher= United Methodist News Service |accessdate = 2008-04-29 }} Finally, gay rights groups have expressed concerns that the church to which Holsinger belongs, Hope Springs United Methodist Church, had a program that tries to "cure" gays.{{cite web |date = June 1, 2007 |author = Jester, Art |url = http://www.tugsa.net/Holsinger.html |title = Holsinger's church role scrutinized |publisher = [[Lexington Herald-Leader]] |accessdate = 2007-07-22 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928074437/http://www.tugsa.net/Holsinger.html |archivedate = September 28, 2007 |df = }}{{cite web |date=June 8, 2007 |url= http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,279032,00.html |title= Bush Surgeon General Nominee Condemned By Gay Groups |publisher= [[Fox News]] |accessdate=2007-07-19}}{{cite web |date=May 31, 2007 |author= Roehr, Bob |url= http://ebar.com/news/article.php?sec=news&article=1878 |title= Surgeon general pick concerns LGBT leaders |publisher= [[Bay Area Reporter]] |accessdate=2007-07-22}} However, the church's pastor denied this. Supporters have pointed out that Holsinger faced down state legislators who, objecting to a session on lesbian health issues at a 2002 women's health conference, threatened to withhold funds. A former co-worker who is lesbian wrote that although a "liberal Democrat", she strongly supported Holsinger as a leader with integrity. ===Public health stances=== ====Smoking==== Holsinger has been a strong advocate for tobacco restrictions, implementing [[smoking bans]] in the entire [[Veterans Health Administration|VA]] hospital systemCondo, Adam. Smoking Ban Opposed for Veterans' Hospitals. The Kentucky Post. page 1K. January 16, 1992 and pushing to increase the [[Excise tax in the United States|excise tax]] on cigarettes from 3 cents to 75 cents (ultimately raised to 30 cents) in a tobacco-growing state.{{cite web |date=May 26, 2007 |url= http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=LH&p_theme=lh&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_dispstring=Pick%20Him%20Holsinger%20good%20choice%20for%20surgeon%20general%20AND%20date(all)&p_field_advanced-0=&p_text_advanced-0=(Pick%20Him%20Holsinger%20good%20choice%20for%20surgeon%20general)&xcal_numdocs=20&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&xcal_useweights=no |title= Pick him – Holsinger good choice for surgeon general |publisher= [[Lexington Herald Leader]] |accessdate=2007-07-22}}{{cite web |date=January 22, 2007 |author= Ward, Karla |url= http://www.lcltfb.org/tobacco/tdn/TND-040122.html |title= Poll Finds Support; Its Advocates In Legislature Hopeful |publisher= [[Lexington Herald-Leader]] |accessdate=2007-07-20 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070929020746/http://www.lcltfb.org/tobacco/tdn/TND-040122.html |archivedate = 2007-09-29}} At his confirmation hearing, Holsinger said one of his top three priorities is "making America a tobacco-free nation". ====Childhood obesity==== Holsinger has consistently aired concerns about childhood obesity, pushing for a limit on [[junk food]] in schools, lobbying and educating for the promotion of exercise and improvements of school nutrition.{{cite web |date=May 26, 2007 |author= Isaacs, Barbara |url= http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=LH&p_theme=lh&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_text_search-0=Holsinger%20AND%20familiar%20AND%20obesity%20AND%20issue&s_dispstring=Holsinger%20familiar%20with%20obesity%20issue%20AND%20date(last%20180%20days)&p_field_date-0=YMD_date&p_params_date-0=date:B,E&p_text_date-0=-180qzD&xcal_numdocs=20&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&xcal_useweights=no |title= Holsinger familiar with obesity issue |publisher= [[Lexington Herald-Leader]] |pages= A1 |accessdate=2007-07-22}}{{cite web |date=May 31, 2007 |url= http://economist.com/world/na/displaystory.cfm?story_id=9256679 |title= Enter Dr Nice Guy |publisher= [[The Economist]] |accessdate=2007-07-22}} He included this as one of his highest priorities at his confirmation hearing. He said he supported banning mass media advertising of junk food geared to children. ====Readiness of Public Health Service Commissioned Corps==== During his confirmation hearings, Holsinger said that if confirmed he would focus on improving the ability of the [[Public Health Service Commissioned Corps]] to respond rapidly to emergencies. ====Embryonic stem-cell research==== In 2002, Holsinger testified at a Kentucky legislative hearing discussing [[stem cell]] research. The [[Christian right]] characterized his testimony as supporting a "loosening [of] regulations". However, the White House said that Holsinger's concerns only involved the severity of the penalties.{{cite web |date=July 9, 2007 |author= Ward, Jon |url= http://washingtontimes.com/article/20070709/NATION/107090065/1001 |title= Bush nominee runs into crossfire |publisher= [[The Washington Times]] |accessdate=2007-07-19}} In 2005, he argued against a Kentucky anti-cloning bill, warning it could restrict future research. Holsinger testified that his father died of [[Parkinson's disease]] which is under investigation for [[gene therapy]].{{cite web |date=June 10, 2007 |author= Wolfson, Andrew |url= http://www.courier-journal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070610/NEWS01/706100522 |archive-url= https://archive.is/20130119211458/http://www.courier-journal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070610/NEWS01/706100522 |dead-url= yes |archive-date= January 19, 2013 |title= Holsinger assailed, defended over views on gays |publisher= [[The Courier-Journal]] |accessdate=2007-07-21}} During the HELP hearing, Holsinger said he supported President [[George W. Bush|Bush's]] stem cell policy, which restricts federal funding to already existing embryonic cell lines while providing funds for adult and animal stem cell research.{{cite web |date=August 10, 2001 |author= Seelye, Katharine Q. |url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?sec=health&res=9D03E1DC123FF933A2575BC0A9679C8B63 |title= The President's decision: the overview; Bush gives his backing for limited research on existing stem cells |publisher= [[The New York Times]] |accessdate=2007-07-20}} ====Sex education==== Holsinger said that [[Sexual abstinence|abstinence education]] is one way to prevent sexually transmitted diseases and unwanted teen pregnancy but also supported educating teenagers about condom use.{{cite web |date = July 12, 2007 |author = Armstrong, Drew |url = http://public.cq.com/docs/cqt/news110-000002549740.html |title = Holsinger Tries to Convince Skeptics He Has Moved Beyond Controversial Paper |publisher = [[Congressional Quarterly]] |accessdate = 2007-07-19 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070716183128/http://public.cq.com/docs/cqt/news110-000002549740.html |archivedate = July 16, 2007 |df = }} ====Morning after pill==== Holsinger said he did not support restricting the availability of an emergency contraceptive known as the [[Emergency contraception|morning-after pill]], or [[Levonorgestrel|Plan B]]. ====Health insurance industry==== During the HELP hearing, Holsinger stated that he would seek ways to help the uninsured. "I think we need to have every American covered for health care." He offered no opinion on how to achieve this goal. He said that he supported banning drug companies from advertising on television.{{cite web |date=July 12, 2007 |author= Dunham, Will |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/politicsNews/idUSN1139581620070712 |title= Bush surgeon general nominee denies he's anti-gay |publisher= [[Reuters]] |accessdate=2007-07-19}} ====Independence of the office of Surgeon General==== Two days before the HELP confirmation hearing, former Surgeon General [[Richard Carmona]] went public with claims that the Bush Administration censored his speeches and buried his scientific reports.{{cite web |date=July 16, 2007 |author= Rovner, Julie |url= https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=11854247 |title= Ex-Surgeon General Says Administration Interfered |publisher= [[National Public Radio]] |accessdate=2007-07-19}} When asked about this at the hearing, Holsinger said, "If I were faced with a situation that I felt I could not in good conscience do, I think I have a clear response to that. I would resign." ==See also== {{portal|United States Army}} *[[United States Department of Veterans Affairs]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.surgeongeneral.gov/ Office of the Surgeon General]. United States Department of Health and Human Services homepage. *[https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2007/05/20070524-2.html President Bush Nominates Dr. James Holsinger Jr. as Surgeon General], White House press release, May 24, 2007. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110719031014/http://news.uky.edu/news/display_article.php?artid=2325 UK, State Officials Praise Nomination of James Holsinger], University of Kentucky press release, May 25, 2007. *[https://nyx.uky.edu/fa/findingaid/?id=xt7w0v89kn8q Guide to the James Holsinger collection on military documents], housed at the University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Holsinger, James W.}} [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Kansas City, Kansas]] [[Category:State cabinet secretaries of Kentucky]] [[Category:Duke University alumni]] [[Category:People from Kentucky]] [[Category:Sexual orientation and medicine]] [[Category:University of Kentucky alumni]] [[Category:University of Kentucky faculty]] [[Category:University of South Carolina alumni]] [[Category:United States Army generals]] [[Category:Recipients of the Distinguished Service Medal (United States)]] [[Category:Recipients of the Legion of Merit]] [[Category:Asbury Theological Seminary alumni]] [[Category:American United Methodists]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1)
revision.text:
[[File:Gunla bajan performance.jpg|thumb|200px|Kansakar Gunla Bajan band performing at Kathmandu Durbar Square.]] [[File:Kel tol sign.jpg|thumb|200px|Kel Tol road sign]] '''Kansakār''' ([[Devanagari]]: कंसकार) or '''Kasāh''' (कसाः) is a Nepalese caste group belonging to the [[Newar]] community of the [[Kathmandu Valley]] in [[Nepal]]. In [[Sanskrit]], Kansakar means bronze worker, and their traditional occupation has been metal working and trading.<ref>{{cite web | last =Lewis| first =Todd T.| url = http://college.holycross.edu/faculty/tlewis/PDFs/Buddhist_Merchants_in_Kathmandu.pdf| title =Buddhist Merchants in Kathmandu: The Asan Twah Market and Uray Social Organization| work = Contested Hierarchies| publisher = Oxford: Clarendon Press| date=1995| accessdate = 26 March 2012}} Page 47.</ref><ref>{{cite web | last =Wright| first =Daniel| url = https://archive.org/stream/HistoryOfNepal/HistoryOfNepaldanielWright_djvu.txt| title =History of Nepal with an Introductory Sketch of the Country and People of Nepal| work = | publisher =Cambridge| date=1877| accessdate = 23 September 2012}} Page 86.</ref> Today, they are merchants, industrialists and professionals.
They are part of the [[Uray (caste group)|Urāy]] (उराय्) group which includes [[Tuladhar]], [[Tamrakar]], [[Sthapit]], [[Bania (Newar caste)|Bania]], Sindurakar, Selalik and other castes.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lewis|first=Todd T.|title=Notes on the Uray and the Modernization of Newar Buddhism|url=http://www.thlib.org/static/reprints/contributions/CNAS_23_01_08.pdf|accessdate=25 March 2012|newspaper=Contributions to Nepalese Studies|date=January 1996}} Page 110.</ref> The Urāy are a community of high-caste Buddhist merchants, and their family names indicate artisan and mercantile specialists.<ref>{{cite web | last =Lewis| first =Todd T.| url = http://college.holycross.edu/faculty/tlewis/PDFs/Buddhist_Merchants_in_Kathmandu.pdf| title =Buddhist Merchants in Kathmandu: The Asan Twah Market and Uray Social Organization| work = Contested Hierarchies| publisher = Oxford: Clarendon Press| date=1995| accessdate = 26 March 2012}} Page 47.</ref> Their religion is [[Newar Buddhism]]<ref>{{cite web| last =Locke| first =John K.| url =http://www.niem.com.np/newararticles/unique_features.htm| title =Unique Features of Newar Buddhism| work =| publisher =Nagarjuna Institute of Exact Methods| date =2008| accessdate =25 March 2012| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20120324221525/http://www.niem.com.np/newararticles/unique_features.htm| archivedate =24 March 2012| df =}}</ref> and mother tongue [[Nepal Bhasa]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Lewis|first=Todd T|title=Buddhism, Himalayan Trade, and Newar Merchants|url=http://buddhim.20m.com/8-4.htm/|accessdate=25 March 2012}}</ref>
Kansakars have been traditionally based in Kel Tol in the historical section of [[Kathmandu]] where they play a major cultural role. The neighborhood is famed for the sacred courtyard of Jana Baha (Machhendra Bahal) where the central temple houses an image of Aryavalokitesvara (Sacred [[Avalokiteśvara]]), a [[Buddhist]] deity popularly known as Jana Baha Dyah or White Machhendranath<ref>{{cite web | last =Locke, S.J.| first =John K.| url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/54318635/1John-Locke-Newar-Buddhist-Initiation-Rites| title =Newar Buddhist Initiation Rites| work = INAS Journal| publisher = | date=| accessdate = 26 March 2012}} Page 2.</ref> (alternative name: White Karunamaya).<ref>{{cite web | last =Yoshizaki| first =Kazumi| url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/30857088/Yoshizaki-Kazumi-NewarBuddhism| title =The Kathmandu Valley as a Water Pot: Abstracts of research papers on Newar Buddhism in Nepal| work = | publisher = | date=2006| accessdate = 29 March 2012}} Page 5.</ref>
==Traditional occupation==
According to the division of labour laid down from ancient times, Kansakars practiced the hereditary occupation of making utensils of bronze. Kitchen and ritual vessels, various types of dinner plates and cymbals are their main products. A dinner plate with a grooved border known as ''siphala dema'' (सिफाला देमा) is their specialty. Bronze is made in their workshops by melting copper and tin and mixing them in a charcoal-fired furnace.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kasāh|first=Dev Ratna|title=Kasāhtaygu Jya |url= |accessdate=|newspaper= Udāy Samā|date=26 July 2003}} Page 23.</ref>
They were also major players in the traditional [[Tibet]] trade, and maintained business houses in [[Lhasa]] in Tibet and in [[Kalimpong]] and [[Kolkata]] in India.<ref>Hilker, DS Kansakar (2005), ''Syamukapu: The Lhasa Newars of Kalimpong and Kathmandu'', Kathmandu: Vajra Publications. {{ISBN|99946-644-6-8}}.</ref>
==Cultural life==
Kansakars participate in the annual chariot procession of Aryavalokitesvara which is known as [[Jana Baha Dyah Jatra]] by playing long horns. The Kansakar [[Gunla Bajan]] musical band organizes performances of religious music during the hold month of Gunla and other festivals.
The 12-yearly [[Samyak]] is the most spectacular Newar Buddhist festival held in Kathmandu where statues of [[Dipankara Buddha]] are displayed. Each Urāy caste has been assigned a duty in the festival from ancient times, and Kansakars have the task of preparing and serving five types of foods.<ref>{{cite web | last =Lewis| first =Todd T.| url = http://college.holycross.edu/faculty/tlewis/PDFs/Buddhist_Merchants_in_Kathmandu.pdf| title =Buddhist Merchants in Kathmandu: The Asan Twah Market and Uray Social Organization| work = Contested Hierarchies| publisher = Oxford: Clarendon Press| date=1995| accessdate = 26 March 2012}} Pages 51-52.</ref>
Kansakars participate in the [[Kumha Pyakhan dance]] (also known as Kumar Pyakhan) which is held annually during the [[Mohani]] festival in October on the open-air dance platform at Asan and at Kathmandu [[Durbar Square]]. A young Tuladhar or Kansakar boy is chosen to be the dancer.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Hoek, Bert van den |author2=Shrestha, Balgopal|title=Guardians of the Royal Goddess: Daitya and Kumar as the Protectors of Taleju Bhavani of Kathmandu|url=http://www.thlib.org/static/reprints/contributions/CNAS_19_02_03.pdf|accessdate=27 March 2012|newspaper=CNAS Journal|date=July 1992}} Page 192.</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Lewis|first=Todd T.|title=Notes on the Uray and the Modernization of Newar Buddhism|url=http://www.thlib.org/static/reprints/contributions/CNAS_23_01_08.pdf|accessdate=27 March 2012|newspaper=Contributions to Nepalese Studies|date=January 1996}} Page 112.</ref>
==Notable Kansakars==
* [[Bhaju Ratna Kansakar]] (1882-1956), trader and philanthropist * [[Daya Bir Singh Kansakar]] (1911-2001), social worker * Gyan Jyoti Kansakar (1921-2004), trader, benefactor and industrialist * Maniharsha Jyoti (1917-1993), trader and industrialist * [[Prem Bahadur Kansakar]] (1918-1991), freedom fighter, author and language activist * [[Vidyabati Kansakar]] (1906-1976), pioneer of nursing * [[Yogbir Singh Kansakar]] (1885-1942), poet * [[Drishti Kansakar]] (1990–present), young entrepreneur
==See also== * [[Lhasa Newar (trans-Himalayan traders)]] * [[Gunla Bajan]] music * [[Kumha Pyakhan dance]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Newar]] [[Category:People from Kathmandu]] [[Category:Nepalese people]] [[Category:Nepalese society]] [[Category:Social groups of Nepal]] [[Category:Newar caste system]] [[Category:Newari-language surnames]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/184.69.78.126|184.69.78.126]] ([[User talk:184.69.78.126|talk]]) to last version by 89.153.121.169
revision.text:
'''Khazen''' (also "El-Khazen", and in some cases Al Khazen or De Khazen, [[Arabic]]: الخازن) is the name of a prominent noble [[Levant]]ine family and clan based in [[Keserwan District]], [[Lebanon]], [[Damascus]], [[Syria]], [[Nablus]], [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]], as well as other districts around the [[Levant]], predominantly in the [[Galilee]]. The Khazen family originally [[Druze]] Arabs later converted to [[Maronite]] [[Christians]], have traced their lineage through DNA testing to [[Jericho]], [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]] (also known as Tell el-Sultan) 8500 B.C.{{sfn|National Geographic DNA Project}}{{Citation needed|date=January 2018|reason=Reference given leads nowhere. The ancestry claimed may also be less unusual than it might appear at first sight.}} Several members have played leading roles in [[politics of Lebanon|politics]] for many generations. [[Louis XIV of France|King Louis XIV]] elevated the family to the [[French nobility]] and referred to them as "princes of the [[Maronites]]" in many letters. [[Pope Clement X]] made them [[Count palatine|Counts Palatine]]. Most of the Lebanese Khazen branch is Maronite, while other branches are Greek Orthodox and Muslim but are not related to the Mount-Lebanese, which were endowed with these honors.
==History== The Khazen [[Cheikhs]] can trace back their lineage to the 9th century, when they were mainly located between [[Houran]], [[Damascus]], [[Baalbeck]], and [[Nablus]]. They started buying and acquiring lands in [[Mount Lebanon]] during the 15th century and, more specifically, first in [[Jaj]] (currently in [[Jbeil District]]). They continued their exodus to the Keserwan district, where they bought lands from the [[Shi'a]] tribes. This caused the Shi'a to move towards what is known today as the South of Lebanon and the Maronites to the Keserwan district.
In 1584, the Khazen were able to hide the princes [[Fakhr-al-Din II|Fakhreddine]] and Younès in Ballouneh. At that time, their father, cornered by the Ottoman's army and losing the fight against them, informed his wife Sitt Nossab to send his sons to the Khazen, a powerful and influential family at that time. The great Fakhreddine, when he took power, was greatly influenced by the Khazen family politically and religiously. In return, he granted them the title of ''[[Cheikh]]'' and complete political influence and control of [[Mount Lebanon]].<ref>2004 Maronite Synod, ''[http://www.maronite-heritage.com/LNE.php?page=File3text19 The Maronite Church and Politics]'', § 10 & 11. Quote: "When the Ottoman state became displeased with the emirs of the ‘Assaf family and with their aides from the Hobeish family, they endeavored to gradually eliminate them, replacing them with the princes of the Bani Sayfa family. The latter, too, were from the Turkmen tribes, brought in by the Ottoman state to protect the shores. However, they used to rule according to the Shari’a, and not according to civil convention. During that period, the Maronite migration toward the southern regions of Mount Lebanon coincided with their contact with Rome and the West through the Franciscan missionaries and other Christian organizations working in the Holy Land. They soon started a new partnership, first with the Ma’an family and prince Fakhreddin, through the Khazen family and, in a second stage, with the Abi-l-Lama’ family. Fakhreddin aspired to gain independence from the Ottoman Empire and wished to be open to the West. ... During that period, harmony was complete, not just between the Maronite Church and the Lebanese Emirate with the different confessions and beliefs of the princes, but also between the Church and the new Maronite leadership, such as the Hobeish and Khazen families, among others. These were, unlike the Mouqaddams, very zealous for the interests of the Church."</ref> Similarly, the Khazen also gave shelter to Prince Haidar [[Chehab family|Shehab]]'s sons, in Keserwan in the early 18th century.<ref>Antoine Khoury Harb, ''The Maronites: History and Constants'', p. 116. Quote: "When Prince Ahmad Maan died, the Shehabs, relatives of the Maan, took over. When the regent Prince Bashir I passed away in 1706, Prince Haidar reigned, and moved the seat of the emirate from Hasbaya to Deir el-Qamar. The Ottoman Wali of Sidon deposed the Shehabi Prince and replaced him by the leader of the Yamani party, Prince Yussef Alam - Eddin. Haidar fled with his two sons and some of his followers to Ghazir in Kisrawan where his allies, the Khazen and Hobeish families from the Qaysi party, were in control. When the army of Prince Yussef Alam-Eddin conquered and burnt Ghazir, Haidar left his sons in Kisrawan and took refuge in Hermel. The sheikhs of the Khazen family offered hiding-places to the prince's family."</ref>
The Khazen families, who were now controlling the Kerserwan district, were very influential within the [[Maronite Church]]. This is due to their financial support of the Church and their assistance in its expansion by the construction of many monasteries, several of which they still own today, as well as their connections to the French.<ref>Matti Moosa, ''The Maronites in History'', p. 283. Quote: "We have also seen earlier that the Maronite community had been placed under the protection of France and that the French kings began to choose their consuls from among the Maronite dignitaries. Through the power and prestige of France the consuls then exercised authority over the Maronite Church and its clergy. The Maronites were so proud to be under the protection of France that some Maronites called themselves, 'the French of the East.' Thus, through France, the Shihabi amirs, who will be discussed shortly, realized the importance of Maronite rule and power, and they and the Maronites became united in a common interest. In 1697, Amir Ahmad died without an heir, and the Druze notables chose his nephew Bashir al-Shihabi as their new ruler. He was succeeded in 1707 by the young Amir Haydar al-Shihabi, grandson of Amir Ahmad al-Ma'ni. Haydar recognized the authority of the Maronite al-Khazins and the Hubayshis of Kisrawan and Ghazir and treated these two families as equal to the feudalistic Druze families." [https://books.google.com/books?id=8Ogp94y8CJgC&pg=PA283#v=onepage&q&f=false]</ref> They also offered lands and, most importantly, supplied security to the Church and the Maronite community overall. In 1656, Cheikh Abou Nawfal received a [[Papal Orders of Chivalry|Papal decoration]] for his help in the expansion of the Maronite faith in Mount Lebanon. The family was consulted on each patriarchal election and controlled episcopal nominations for three Maronite [[archbishop]]rics—representing the districts of [[Aleppo]], [[Baalbeck]], and [[Damascus]]—until the 19th century.<ref>Richard Van Leeuwen, ''Notables and Clergy in Mount Lebanon: The Khāzin Sheikhs and the Maronite Church (1736-1840)'', p. 103-104. Quote: "The influence of the Khāzin sheiks in clerical matters concentrated on two aspects, which were, as far as the clergy were concerned, closely interrelated: the nomination of prelates and the founding and administration of clerical and monastic possessions. Traditionally, the main Maronite nobles were consulted on the occasion of the election of the patriarch. ... Eventually, the three main branches of the Khāzin family acquired the privilege of selecting the ''mutrāns'' of the dioceses of Aleppo (''awlād'' Abī Nasīf), Baalbek (''awlād'' Abī Qānsawh), and Damascus (''awlād'' Abī Nawfal). This privilege was acknowledged by Patriarch Ya'qūb 'Awwād. It is, therefore, evident that the Khāzin sheiks also interfered in dioceses which officially had no connection with their administrative territory, an indication that they saw their role in church matters as an extension of their political power within the community as a whole." (''[http://khazen.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2094:election-of-the-maronite-patriarch-history&catid=141:khazen-blog&Itemid=213 Text also available here]''.)</ref><ref>Farid el-Khazen, ''The Breakdown of the State in Lebanon, 1967-1976'', p. 35. Quote: "By the mid-19th century, the church and its monastic orders were present in various areas of the Mountain. Its power had surpassed that of the lordly Maronite families, notably the Khazen family, on which it had previously depended for protection and support. 'By the end of the 18th century,' writes Iliya Harik, the 'church had become the largest, the most organized, and the wealthiest organization in the whole of Mount Lebanon.' It established educational institutions in various parts of the Mountain and had an educated and active clergy. By the time the ''Mutasarrifiyya'' was established, the Maronite Patriarch emerged as the de facto central political figure in Mount Lebanon." [https://books.google.com/books?id=TQdheeeXQCgC&pg=PA35#v=onepage&q&f=false]</ref> There were three important and influential patriarchs from the Khazen family: [[Joseph Dergham El Khazen|Youssef Dargham]] (1733–1742), [[Tobias El Khazen|Toubia]] (1756–1766) and [[Joseph Ragi El Khazen|Youssef Ragi]] (1845–1854). Several bishops have also shared the name, including [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/belkhm.html Michel] (Caesarea, 1767-1786), [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/belkhi.html Ignace] (Nablus, 1787-1819), [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/belkhg.html Germanos] (Damascus, 1794-1806), [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/belkhe.html Estefan] (Damascus, 1806-1830), [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/bgazen.html Anton] (Baalbeck, 1807-1858), [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/bgazeno.html Estefan] (Damascus, 1848-1868), [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/belkh.html Louis Joseph] (Ptolemais, 1919-1933), and [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/baboukh.html Georges Abou] (Rusadus, 2014-current).
In 1858, [[Tanius Shahin|Tanios Chahine]] started a [[Tanyus Shahin#Leadership of peasants' revolt|rebellion]] against the Khazen family, which caused a great loss to their dominance over Kerserwan. The rebellion was a result of a power struggle between the Abi Lamaa family, the [[England|English]], the [[France|French]], the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottomans]], and particular Khazen who wanted to increase their influence.<ref>William Harris, ''Lebanon: A History, 600-2011'', p. 162. Quote: "After 1860, France and Britain converged in protecting their stakes in the empire against Russian encroachment. French defeat by Prussia in 1870 made France more risk averse. French interest in Maronite clerical turf struggles with governors waned; indeed, France was the chief architect of the eventual competitor of the church -- the elected administrative council. France was schizophrenic in upholding both the Ottomans and its own influence in Mount Lebanon and Syria. Davud Pasha, an Armenian Catholic, developed fruitful relations with foreign consuls and strong local commitment. These were assets in resuscitating the local secular elite. In the Kisrawan, Davud reconciled the Khazen sheikhs and the peasants, the former retrieving much of their property and the latter mollified with tax and land concessions." [https://books.google.com/books?id=J-EvNaeh6gsC&pg=PA162]</ref> After these events, the Khazen stayed involved in politics, yet their work as one family holding ultimate Maronite power has diminished greatly.
The Khazen crest, which includes snowy mountains and a cedar tree, reflects the family's special closeness to the country, and especially to Mount Lebanon.<ref>[http://catholicanalysis.files.wordpress.com/2014/07/khazen.png The Khazen Crest] (image).</ref>
There are multiple branches of the family. The 2 main branches are based in [[Ajaltoun]], which mainly traces its origins from Nawfal Abou Nassif el-Khazen (son of Nader Abou Nawfal el-Khazen), and [[Ghosta, Mount Lebanon|Ghosta]], which mainly traces its origins from Fayad Abou Kanso el-Khazen (son of Nader Abou Nawfal; also, consul of France).<ref>[http://khazen.org/genealogical_tree Khazen Genealogical Tree]. See ''Nader Abou Nawfal'' and his list of children.</ref> Kfardebian, which is nearby, also has a sizable branch.
==Today==
In modern times, Khazen have always represented [[Keserwan]] with at least one [[Member of Parliament|MP]] in the [[Parliament of Lebanon|Lebanese Parliament]]. They have also been represented in many recent governments. Prominent politicians include Cheikh Philippe El Khazen, a prominent doctor and medical professor born in 1921 in Ghosta. Cheikh Philippe El Khazen was a member of the Parliament in 1968-1972 and a Co-Founder and Vice President of the Maronite League. He was also a member of the European Christian Democratic Party. Cheikh Elias Choukrallah El Khazen, minister and deputy born in 1927 from Ajaltoun, was a member of Parliament in 1964, 1972, 1992, 1996 and Minister of Interior from 1989 - 1990. Cheikh Elias Choukrallah El Khazen as a deputy signed the Taef agreement to end the Lebanese civil war and to return to political normalcy in Lebanon. Cheikh Wadih El Khazen, minister of Tourism, Feb 2005, and president of The Central Maronite Council since January 2006.[[Walid el-Khazen]], former ambassador from the [[Sovereign Military Order of Malta]] to [[Jordan]],<ref>[http://www.khazen.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=156 Cheikh Walid El Khazen]. Khazen.org.</ref> [[Amine el-Khazen]], former Lebanese ambassador to the [[United Nations]],<ref>[http://khazen.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=585 Cheikh Amine El Khazen]. Khazen.org.</ref> [[Farid Haykal el-Khazen]], former Tourism Minister,<ref>http://faridelkhazen.com</ref><ref>[http://khazen.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=847&Itemid=0 Cheikh Farid Haykal El Khazen]. Khazen.org. ([https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=auto&tl=en&js=y&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&u=http%3A%2F%2Fkhazen.org%2Findex.php%3Foption%3Dcom_content%26task%3Dview%26id%3D847%26Itemid%3D0&edit-text= English Translation])</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4277779.stm Lebanon tourism minister resigns]. BBC News. Published: 18 February 2005.</ref><ref>[http://www.khazen.org/picture1/displayimage.php?album=12&pos=54 Farid Haykal with Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir] ([http://khazen.org/picture1/displayimage.php?pos=-125 Alternative Link])</ref> and [[Farid Elias el-Khazen]], professor and past Chairman of Political Studies at the [[American University of Beirut]] and current MP.<ref>http://www.aub.edu.lb/fas/pspa/people/Pages/El-Khazen.aspx</ref> Noteworthy businessmen include Fady el-Khazen, former director for the Ministry of Agriculture and owner of French restaurant ''La Creperie'',<ref>http://lacreperielb.com/</ref><ref>[http://khazen.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1505&Itemid=1 Cheikh Fady El Khazen Profile]. Khazen.org.</ref><ref>http://www.khazen.org/picture1/displayimage.php?album=12&pos=7 ([http://khazen.org/picture1/displayimage.php?pos=-39 Alternative Link])</ref><ref>http://www.khazen.org/picture1/displayimage.php?album=12&pos=8 ([http://www.khazen.org/picture1/displayimage.php?pos=-44 Alternative Link])</ref> Chafic el-Khazen, the CEO of Sky Management,<ref>http://sky-management.net/#about_us/the_team</ref><ref>[http://dailystar.com.lb/Culture/Lifestyle/2014/Jan-31/246029-o1ne-aims-to-replicate-skybars-success-in-winter-season.ashx O1NE aims to replicate SKYBAR’s success in winter season]. ''The Daily Star'', Lebanon. Published: 31 January 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.thebusinessyear.com/publication/article/32/2918/lebanon-2013/trip-the-light FOCUS: Trip the Light]. ''The Business Year''.</ref> and Fouad el-Khazen, honorary chairman of the BIT bank.<ref>http://www.bitbank.com.lb/board-of-directors.php</ref><ref>[http://www.dailystar.com.lb/Business/Local/2014/Jul-04/262570-bit-and-necb-banks-merge-with-combined-assets-of-11m.ashx BIT and NECB banks merge with combined assets of $1.1B]. ''The Daily Star'', Lebanon. Published: 4 July 2014.</ref><ref>[http://khazen.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&id=124&Itemid=231 Cheikh Fouad el Khazen]. Khazen.org.</ref><ref>[http://www.mondanite.net/photos/44060/the-ambassador-of-italy-and-his-wife-fouad-el-khaz Fouad with Italian Ambassador to Lebanon Giuseppe Morabito and others]. ''Mondanite''. ([http://www.mondanite.net/GalleryImages/Gal-P-44060-634986987870759531.JPG Image])</ref><ref>[http://www.mondanite.net/photos/13743/the-turkish-ambassador-and-fouad-el-khazen Fouad with Turkish Ambassador to Lebanon Suleiman Inan Ozyildiz]. ''Mondanite''. ([http://www.mondanite.net/GalleryImages/Gal-P-13743-634850508429062500.jpg Image])</ref>

revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Iranian Turkmen}} {{ethnic group| |group=Khorasani Turks |image= |population=approx. 400,000-1,000,000<ref>[http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/turkic-languages-overview Iranicaonline]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Z7i5CAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false The Turkic Languages, By Lars Johanson, Éva Ágnes Csató Johanson, page 13, Routledge, 2015]</ref> |popplace=[[North Khorasan]], [[Razavi Khorasan]], [[Golestan Province|Golestan]] |rels= [[Shia Islam]] |langs= [[Khorasani Turkic language|Khorasani Turkic]] and [[Persian language|Persian]] |related= Other [[Turkic peoples]]}} '''Khorasani Turks''' ({{lang-fa|ترک‌های خراسان}}, [[Khorasani Turkic language|Khorasani Turkish]]:''خوراسان تؤرکلری''; often described as '''[[Qizilbash]]'''){{citation needed|date=June 2017}} are a [[Turkic peoples|Turkic]] [[ethnic group]] inhabiting part of [[North Khorasan Province|North Khorasan]], [[Razavi Khorasan Province|Razavi Khorasan]] and [[Golestan Province|Golestan]] provinces of Iran, as well as in the neighboring regions of [[Turkmenistan]] up to beyond the [[Amu Darya River]], and speak [[Khorasani Turkic language|Khorasani Turkic]].
The Khorasani Turks are not to be confused with other Turkic groups which have arrived in Khorasan more recently, especially [[Iranian Azerbaijanis]], who had a presence in the area, especially in [[Mashhad]], from about the early 20th century.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/azerbaijan-vi |title=AZERBAIJAN vi. Population and its Occupations and Culture |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Iranica]] |date= August 18, 2011 |accessdate=13 August 2013}}</ref>
[[File:Nader Shah Afshar.jpg|200px|thumb|right|[[Nader Shah]] was a Khorasani Turk]]
==Tribes of Khorasani Turks== ;Bayat Lives mainly in [[Nishapur]].
;Qarachordu Lives mainly in [[Isfarayen County|Isfarayen]].
;Imarli, Bukanli, Cuyanli, Pehlivanli, Boranli and Kilicanli Lives mainly in [[Bojnord County|Bojnord]].
;Timurtash and Nardin Lives in [[Gorgan]] city center.
;Godari Lives in [[Sini, Razavi Khorasan|Sini]].
;Afshar Lives in most areas of [[Greater Khorasan]].
;Ramiani Lives in [[Ramian]], [[Azadshahr]] and Gonbad-e Kavous counties of [[Golestan province]].
;Hajilari Lives in [[Minoodasht]], [[Galikesh]], [[Kalaleh]], Gonbad-e Kavous counties of [[Golestan province]].
;Qarayi Lives in [[Torbat-e Heydarieh County|Torbat-e Heydarieh]].<ref>[http://journal.qu.edu.az/article_pdf/1011_133.pdf] HORASAN AĞIZLARI</ref>
==Notable Khorasani Turks== * [[Haj Ghorban Soleimani]] * [[Nader Shah]]
==See also== *[[Khorasani Turkic language]] *[[Qarai Turks]]

'''Lukomorye''', '''Lukomorie''' or '''Lukomorje''' ({{lang-ru|Лукомо́рье}}) is a fictional land in [[Russia]]n [[folklore]] and [[history]]. The Russian word itself is an obsolete term for "[[bight (geography)|bight]]" or "[[bay]]". In the word "luk-o-mor-ye", "-o-" is an [[infix]] to connect two roots, "-ye" is an [[affix]] (in this case, of relative location), "luk-" is the root for "bend", "mor-" is the root for "sea". It can also be translated as "curved sea-shore" or "inlet of the sea". ==Middle Ages geography and Early Russian manuscripts== The toponym "Sea Bend" (лука моря, ''luka morya'') and the derivations: ''lukomorye'', ''lukomorians'', etc., has been applied to various geographical locations.Энциклопедия [http://feb-web.ru/feb/slovenc/es/es3/es3-1832.htm "Слова о полку Игореве"]: В 5 томах / Рос. акад. наук. Ин-т рус. лит. (Пушкин. дом); Ред. кол.: Л. А. Дмитриев, Д. С. Лихачев, С. А. Семячко, О. В. Творогов (отв. ред.). — СПб.: Дмитрий Буланин, 1995 {{ru icon}} It is mentioned in [[The Tale of Igor's Campaign]] and the Russian chronicles. According to the chronicles Lukomorye was inhabited by the nomadic [[Polovtsy]] people, and the researchers locate it in the region north of the [[Sea of Azov]], where Polovtsy lived in the 11th—12th centuries.{{cite web|url=http://feb-web.ru/feb/pushkin/serial/v95/v95-192-.htm|script-title=ru:К локализации пушкинского Лукоморья|last=Михайлов |first=В. Д. |language=Russian|accessdate=2009-01-13}} These accounts are seen as a source of inspiration for [[Alexander Pushkin]]. In modern [[Russian culture]] the word Lukomorye is most commonly associated with Pushkin's fairy tale poem ''[[Ruslan and Ludmila (poem)|Ruslan and Lyudmila]]'',{{cite book|last1=Nabokov |first1=Vladimir Vladimirovich |last2=Wilson |first2=Edmund |last3=Karlinsky |first3=Simon |title=Dear Bunny, Dear Volodya By|publisher=University of California Press|pages=120|isbn=0520220803|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AstRuYyehzgC&pg=PA120&dq=Lukomorie&ei=28xrSai-NqOOyQSTi-3-Cg}} starting with the line: "There is a green oak-tree by the lukomorye, …" (У лукоморья дуб зелёный, … ; ''U lukomorya dub zelyony, …''). [[File:Lucomoria.jpg|thumb|300px|right|A fragment of a 17th-century map by [[Gerrit van Schagen]] that shows Lucomorie]] The land of "Lucomoria" was also depicted in a number of antique maps of [[Siberia]]/[[Muscovy]].[http://www.helmink.com/Antique_Map_van_Schagen_World/Scans/van%20Schagen%20Asia/slides/Schagen%20Asia%205.html, A fragment of the map of Asia] by [[van Schagen]], 1680 It is suggested that the cartographers followed the descriptions of [[Sigismund von Herberstein]] in his 1549 ''[[Notes on Muscovite Affairs]]:{{cite book|last= von Herberstein|first=Sigismund|title=[[Notes on Muscovite Affairs]]|year=1549|chapter=De Tartaris|chapter-url=http://www.hs-augsburg.de/~harsch/Chronologia/Lspost16/Sigismundus/sig_co04.html#03|quote=''...quas populi Grustintzi & Serponovutzi mercantur, Hi a castro Serponovu Lucomoryae ultra Obi fluvium in montibus sitae nomen habent.
Lucomoryae autem hominibus mirabile quiddam ac incredibile, & fabulae persimile aiunt accidere, quos in singulos annos, nempe XXVII die Novembris, quae apud Ruthenos Sancto Georgio sacra est, mori aiunt: ac vere in sequenti, maxime ad XXIIII Aprilis, ranarum instar, denuo reviviscere.
...
Cossin fluvius ex montibus Lucomoryae delabitur. in huius ostiis Cossin castrum est, quod olim Knes Vuentza, nunc vero illius filii possident.
Eo a Cossin magni fluvii fontibus, est iter duorum mensium. Porro ex eiusdem fluvii fontibus alter fluvius Cassima oritur, emensaque Lucomorya in magnum fluvium Tachnin influit: ultra quem prodigiosae formae homines habitare dicuntur, quorum alii ferarum more, toto corpore pilis horrent: alii caninis capitibus, alii prorsus sine collo pectus pro capite habent, longasque sine pedibus manus.}}
...which they barter with the [[:ru:Грустина|Grustintzi]] and Serponovtzi : these latter people derive their name from the fortress of Serponov Lucomoryae, situated in the mountains beyond the [[Ob River|river Oby]].
It is said that a certain marvellous and incredible occurrence, and very like a fable, happens every year to the people of Lucomoryae, namely, that they die on the 27th of November, which among the Russians is dedicated to [[St. George]], and come to life again like the frosts in the following spring, generally on the 24th of April.
...
The Cossin is a river which flows down from the mountains of Lucomorya ; at its mouth is the fortress of Cossin, which was formerly possessed by the Knes Ventza, but now by his sons.
From the sources of the great river Cossin to this point is a journey of two months. Moreover, from the sources of the same river, rises another river Cassima, which, after passing through the district of Lucomorya, flows into the great river Tachnin ; beyond which are said to dwell men of prodigious stature, some of whom are covered all over with hair, like wild beasts, while others have heads like dogs, and others have no necks, their breast occupying the place of a head, while they have long hands, but no feet. Herberstein/note Russi V2, Published by [[Ayer Publishing]] {{ISBN|0-8337-2191-7}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=e9ZoYV3ae7AC&pg=PA40&lpg=PA40&dq=lucomoryae&source=bl&ots=Fh4FkJw3AG&sig=RtAPw2evb4MyE23tlGHYrNj099M&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result pp. 40, 41]
[[Giles Fletcher, the Elder|Giles Fletcher]] in his ''Of the Russe Common Wealth'' repeats the fantastic tale of dying/reviving Lukomorians."The Travellers' Dictionary of Quotation" by Peter Yapp [https://books.google.com/books?id=1649AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA723&lpg=PA723&dq=%22lucomoria%22&source=web&ots=TvKiLB47Pm&sig=vMCIfGa2pVAcdv55nMoLcTEmeh4&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result#PPA723,M1 p. 723] ==See also== * [[Hyperborea]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Slavic mythology}} [[Category:Fictional regions]] [[Category:Locations in Slavic mythology]] [[Category:Russian culture]]
